Headline: Thales Could Easily Finance New Acquisition: CEO
Story: By David Pearson   Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     PARIS (Dow Jones)--France-based defense electronics company Thales SA (12132.FR) hasn't finished its external growth and could finance a substantial acquisition that would boost its key businesses without much difficulty, Chief Executive Denis Ranque said Monday.   Speaking to journalists on the fringes of a New Year's  event, Ranque declined to say whether Thales had been among the bidders for Smiths Group PLC's (SMIN.LN) aerospace business that is being sold to General Electric Co. (GM) for $4.8 billion. But he indicated that Thales wouldn't balk at trying to take over a business this big.   Like most of its big competitors, such as U.S.-based Honeywell International Inc. (HON) and Rockwell Collins Corp. (COL), Thales has been a net acquirer in recent years.   "These days, everyone is going shopping so as to be able to offer as broad a range of products and services as possible," Ranque noted.   Thales' most recent expansion was a EUR1.7 billion deal to buy Alcatel-Lucent's (ALA) space and transport activities, giving it strong footholds in the markets for satellite and infrastructure systems.   Thales also plans to buy a 25% stake in French naval shipbuilder DCN for between EUR100 million and EUR150 million.   Ranque said that if a big acquisition target presents itself - even one as large as GE's purchase of Smiths' operations - Thales would be able to finance such an operation.   "If we were faced with an acquisition of several billion dollars, we'd finance it with a mix of debt and equity, by issuing stock on the market," Ranque said.   Ranque also noted that the company's pending acquisitions haven't negatively affected Thales' credit rating.   He noted that Thales' outstanding debt, which stood at EUR398 million at the end of 2005, had ebbed further over the course of last year. He declined to give a figure for the Dec. 31, 2006, debt level, but observed that "Thales' debt is practically zero."   Thales won't be giving out audited 2006 earnings figures until March 9.   Ranque said 2007 is shaping up to be a year of renewed top-line growth for Thales after several years of flat-line revenue. The Alcatel-Lucent acquisition, which still has to be approved by the European Union Commission, will boost Thales' revenue by EUR1.9 billion this year.   Thales shares closed up 1.4% on Monday at EUR39.90.     -By David Pearson, Dow Jones Newswires; +331 4017 1740, david.pearson@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 15, 2007 14:02 ET (19:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Business Objects and Savvion Partner to Take Performance-Driven Organizations to the Next Level
Story: Companies to Host Webinar Showcasing How Organizations That   Combine Business Intelligence and Business Process Management Can                 Achieve Significant Performance Gains  SAN JOSE, Calif. & SANTA CLARA, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--January 15, 2007--   Business Objects (Nasdaq:BOBJ)(Euronext Paris ISIN code: FR0004026250 - BOB), the world's leading provider of business intelligence (BI) solutions, and Savvion(R), the industry's leading business process management (BPM) company, today announced a strategic technology partnership. This partnership allows organizations to achieve maximum performance by linking business intelligence to actionable business processes. As part of the alliance, Business Objects and Savvion will work closely to help customers integrate their business intelligence and business processes management deployments to achieve maximum value across the enterprise.     "Business process management software provides the final step so organizations can leverage the most out of their BI solutions," said Patrick Morrissey, senior vice president of marketing and business development at Savvion. "Business intelligence surfaces the problem so that business managers can work toward improvement. Intelligence and analytics combined with BPM are a natural fit to deliver actionable, complete, and real world solutions that take organizations to the next performance level."     "The ability to unlock the power of intelligence is connected to an organization's ability to define and improve their current processes, and then make them actionable," said Wyatt Mullin, vice president of global ISV channels at Business Objects. "Integrating business intelligence and business process management creates a perfect marriage and offers organizations a powerful way to transform their business and achieve competitive advantage. We are pleased to add Savvion to our growing list of Technology Alliance Partners and look forward to working with them on joint customer engagements."     Business Objects recently announced BusinessObjects(TM) XI Release 2 Productivity Suite, a new set of capabilities to enhance simplicity for end users, greater scalability and performance for enterprise information management (EIM), and improved efficiency for IT. Part of the new solution is geared toward operational BI, which delivers real time data to users within daily business processes -- whether they're on the phone with a customer or on the road with inventory -- so they can make quick, informed decisions. With new web services focused on operational BI, Business Objects will now provide enhanced integration with Savvion BusinessManager(TM) 7.0 to ensure that BI is an integral part of business operations. For example, a procurement manager can use BI within a BPM application to monitor how well vendors are delivering against their contracts.       Web Seminar -- Making Intelligence Actionable     To learn more about how organizations can combine BI and BPM to achieve significant performance gains and efficiencies, please plan on attending a live web seminar entitled "Making Intelligence Actionable: How BI Combined with BPM Boosts Performance" on Thursday, January 18 at 2:00 p.m. ET/11 a.m. PT. Guy Weismantel, senior director of enterprise performance management marketing at Business Objects and Patrick Morrissey, senior vice president of marketing and business development at Savvion will illustrate how aligning BPM and BI can turn insights into action. To register for the webcast, please go to http://www.sharedinsights.com/events/webseminars/redir/savvion.asp.       About Business Objects     Business Objects is the world's leading business intelligence (BI) software company, with more than 39,000 customers worldwide, including over 80 percent of the Fortune 500. Business Objects helps organizations of all sizes create a trusted foundation for decision making, gain better insight into their business, and optimize performance. The company's innovative business intelligence suite, BusinessObjects(TM) XI, offers the BI industry's most advanced and complete solution for performance management, planning, reporting, query and analysis, and enterprise information management. BusinessObjects XI includes the award-winning Crystal line of reporting and data visualization software. Business Objects has also built the industry's strongest and most diverse partner community, and offers consulting and education services to help customers effectively deploy their business intelligence projects.     Business Objects has dual headquarters in San Jose, Calif., and Paris, France. The company's stock is traded on both the Nasdaq (BOBJ) and Euronext Paris (ISIN: FR0004026250 - BOB) stock exchanges. More information about Business Objects can be found at www.businessobjects.com.       About Savvion     Savvion is the leading provider of business process management (BPM) software that improves business performance and reduces costs. Savvion has a proven track record of turning process improvement ideas into real-world solutions quickly, often in as few as 30 days, and delivering a return on investment as high as 300%. More than 300 global business enterprises, public service agencies, and systems integration firms, including 20 of the Fortune 100, use Savvion systems to manage their business. Savvion is recognized by Intelligent Enterprise as one of the most influential companies in information technology today, and is a Leader in the Forrester Wave for BPM. To start down the path of process improvement, download the Savvion Process Modeler available for free at www.savvion.com/startnow. Or visit the Savvion ProcessXchange, where people can connect with a community of interest devoted to business process management, at www.processxchange.com.     Headquartered in Santa Clara, California, Savvion can be reached at www.savvion.com or 888-544-5511.     The Business Objects logo, BusinessObjects, Crystal Reports, Intelligent Question, and Xcelsius are trademarks or registered trademarks of Business Objects in the United States and/or other countries. The Savvion logo, Savvion, and Savvion BusinessManager are trademarks or registered trademarks of Savvion, Inc. All other trademarks mentioned herein are the property of their respective owners. Headline: ING Exercises Pegas Nonwovens Greenshoe Option
Story: PRAGUE (Dow Jones)--ING Bank NV said Monday it has exercised an over-allotment option for shares of Pegas Nonwovens SA (BAAPEGAS.PR), a synthetic fabrics maker, that went public on the Prague and Warsaw exchanges in December.   At its initial public offering Pegas Nonwovens sold 4.385 million shares at EUR27 a share, or 749.2 Czech koruna.   In the over-allotment, exercised Friday, ING subscribed to an additional 657,750 Pegas Nonwovens shares, boosting the company's free float to 54.6% from just below 50%.   The remaining shares of the company are held by Pamplona Capital Partners I LP, part of the London-based Pamplona Capital Management.   In Prague the stock closed up 0.9% at CZK766.6 a share, reflecting the gain of the overall market.   Company Web site: http://www.pegas.cz     -By Leos Rousek, Dow Jones Newswires; +420 221 085 273; leos.rousek@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 15, 2007 14:44 ET (19:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: SonaeCom Reiterates EUR9.5/Shr Portugal Telecom Bid Fair-2
Story: The bid runs until March 9, and there is an extraordinary general meeting expected on Feb. 25 to change Portugal Telecom's bylaws, which limit voting to 10%, and allow Sonaecom to gain control.   "Sonaecom will need to gain the support of two-thirds of shareholders, unlikely at current levels," according to Dresdner Kleinwort.   The final opportunity to raise the offer is Feb. 28 - 10 days before the offer closes. But most analysts say SonaeCom will have to raise its bid by Feb. 20, the last day for shareholders to register, five days before the EGM.   "We expect Sonaecom to raise its offer to between  10.5 and 11.0 (euros) per share by Feb. 20," says Jonathan Dann at Bear Sterns.   The fact that PT shares have consistently been trading above the offer price bolsters speculation of a higher bid. PT shares closed at EUR10.18 Monday, down 0.2%.   An improved offer would also have to be approved by the CMVM, a spokeswoman at the watchdog said.   If its PT takeover is successful, SonaeCom would control roughly 70% of Portugal's mobile telephone subscribers, easily the highest concentration in any Western market.   SonaeCom shares closed up 0.8% at EUR6 after reaching a new six-year intraday high Monday at EUR6.1 in an overall positive market.     Company Web site: http://www.telecom.pt     -By Filipa Cunha, Dow Jones Newswires; +351 21 319 1863; filipa.cunha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 15, 2007 13:45 ET (18:45 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
